Academic Freedom Questioned
As Professor Henry Hornik of the romance languages
department resigns his position to take up an appointment in Israel, he brings some serious charges concerning the "inhibitive" state of academic freedom at Johns
Hopkins. In his statement to the News-Letter, Professor
Hornik cited administration restriction of free expression of ideas and racial intolerance among the causes for
his withdrawal from the Hopkins faculty.
Such complaints have been heard before—but never
from the professioral ranks. If true, Professor Hornik's
pronouncements indicate a serious deterioration of the
academic atmosphere of this university.
We are not in a position to evaluate the validity of
Professor Hornik's complaints. But we are struck by
their urgency and believe that further investigation is in
order. The dean of the faculty of philosophy should
make a thorough investigation of the conditions within
the various departments and the scholars' attitudes concerning these important points.
